title: Jerome Powell
added: On joining the Fed, Powell was not considered a deep expert in macroeconomics or monetary policy; and rather than having strong economic views, Powell was seen as a consensus builder, and a rational fact-based problem solver, who was prepared to visit Capitol Hill frequently to communicate and listen to all views on the economy.<ref name=WP1>{{cite newspaper | newspaper=[[Washington Post]] | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/10/31/jerome-powell-trumps-pick-to-lead-fed-would-be-the-richest-chair-since-the-1940s/ | first=Heather | last=Long | date=2 June 2017 | accessdate=9 November 2020 | title=Who is Jerome Powell, Trump’s pick for the nation’s most powerful economic position?}}</ref>

title: Jerome Powell
added: Powell's adoption of asset bubbles from 2019 onwards, resulted in levels of [[wealth inequality]] not seen in the United States since the 1920s.<ref>{{cite website | url=https://www.axios.com/jerome-powell-federal-reserve-economic-inequality-80446ee0-8e4d-49ee-9ac1-c7f25806fab0.html | title=Jerome Powell's ironic legacy on economic inequality | website=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] | first=Dion | last=Rabouin | date=13 October 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper | newspaper=[[Washington Post]] | title=The global economy is likely to rebound in 2020, but the IMF warns of eerie parallels to the 1920s | first=Heather | last=Long | date=20 January 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/01/20/global-economy-is-likely-rebound-2020-imf-warns-eerie-parallels-roaring-1920s/ }}</ref>  Powell's focus on asset bubbles was also attributed to the [[K-shaped recovery]] that emerged post the coronavirus pandemic, where asset bubbles protected the wealthier segments of society from the financial effects of the pandemic.<ref>{{cite website | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/04/worries-grow-over-a-k-shaped-economic-recovery-that-favors-the-wealthy.html | title=Worries grow over a K-shaped economic recovery that favors the wealthy | first=Jeff | last=Cox | date=4 Septemner 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper | newspaper=[[Financial Times]] | date=19 August 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | url=https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2020/08/19/1597841608000/Yet-another--K-shaped--recovery-data-point/ | title=Yet another 'K-shaped' recovery data point | author=FT Alphaville}}</ref>

title: Jerome Powell
added: Powell's adoption of asset bubbles from 2019 onwards, resulted in levels of [[wealth inequality]] not seen in the United States since the 1920s.<ref>{{cite website | url=https://www.axios.com/jerome-powell-federal-reserve-economic-inequality-80446ee0-8e4d-49ee-9ac1-c7f25806fab0.html | title=Jerome Powell's ironic legacy on economic inequality | website=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] | first=Dion | last=Rabouin | date=13 October 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper | newspaper=[[Washington Post]] | title=The global economy is likely to rebound in 2020, but the IMF warns of eerie parallels to the 1920s | first=Heather | last=Long | date=20 January 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/01/20/global-economy-is-likely-rebound-2020-imf-warns-eerie-parallels-roaring-1920s/ }}</ref>  Powell's focus on asset bubbles was also attributed to the [[K-shaped recovery]] that emerged post the coronavirus pandemic, where asset bubbles protected the wealthier segments of society from the financial effects of the pandemic.<ref>{{cite website | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/04/worries-grow-over-a-k-shaped-economic-recovery-that-favors-the-wealthy.html | title=Worries grow over a K-shaped economic recovery that favors the wealthy | first=Jeff | last=Cox | date=4September2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper | newspaper=[[Financial Times]] | date=19 August 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | url=https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2020/08/19/1597841608000/Yet-another--K-shaped--recovery-data-point/ | title=Yet another 'K-shaped' recovery data point | author=FT Alphaville}}</ref>

title: Jerome Powell
added: Powell's adoption of asset bubbles from 2019 onwards, resulted in levels of [[wealth inequality]] not seen in the United States since the 1920s.<ref>{{cite website | url=https://www.axios.com/jerome-powell-federal-reserve-economic-inequality-80446ee0-8e4d-49ee-9ac1-c7f25806fab0.html | title=Jerome Powell's ironic legacy on economic inequality | website=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] | first=Dion | last=Rabouin | date=13 October 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper | newspaper=[[Washington Post]] | title=The global economy is likely to rebound in 2020, but the IMF warns of eerie parallels to the 1920s | first=Heather | last=Long | date=20 January 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/01/20/global-economy-is-likely-rebound-2020-imf-warns-eerie-parallels-roaring-1920s/ }}</ref>  Powell's focus on asset bubbles was also attributed to the [[Recession shapes|K-shaped recovery]] that emerged post the coronavirus pandemic, where asset bubbles protected the wealthier segments of society from the financial effects of the pandemic.<ref>{{cite website | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/04/worries-grow-over-a-k-shaped-economic-recovery-that-favors-the-wealthy.html | title=Worries grow over a K-shaped economic recovery that favors the wealthy | first=Jeff | last=Cox | date=4 September 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper | newspaper=[[Financial Times]] | date=19 August 2020 | accessdate=11 November 2020 | url=https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2020/08/19/1597841608000/Yet-another--K-shaped--recovery-data-point/ | title=Yet another 'K-shaped' recovery data point | author=FT Alphaville}}</ref>
